text: hey the fellow travelers mark here with
Walters world and today we're gonna
answer a question that Sarah one of our
fellow travelers sent us asking about
airline travel with a wheelchair and so
we I actually reached out to our friend
Joe kleiner from Weald dot travel on
Instagram and he put together this video
to help us out everybody my name is Joe
kleiner I was born with a disability
called spina bifida and I use a
wheelchair to get around now I love to
travel so what I've got for you today
are my top five don'ts of airline travel
for those of us who use wheelchairs
right off the bat my first don't is
don't pack more bags than you can easily
carry by yourself for me personally I
only bring two bags when I travel I've
got my carry-on which is essentially
just a small gym bag that I can sling
over my shoulder and rest on my lap and
then I've got my checked bag which is a
small hard body suitcase on wheels now
with my checked bag because it's on
wheels I can push that in front of my
wheelchair and actually steer myself
just by moving that suitcase in the
direction that I want to go it works
really well for me but you know try some
different things and see what works for
you now my second don't goes along with
the first and that is don't forget to
pack your essential items in your
carry-on for me that would be medical
equipment any medication that might be
on toothbrush toothpaste cologne
deodorant and an extra pair of clothes
everything else you could probably
afford to pack in your checked bag so
all of your extra clothes an extra pair
of shoes a camera a hat anything like
that that although you obviously
wouldn't want to lose you could afford
to lose and you wouldn't necessarily
ruin your vacation if that were to
happen all right so my third don't is
don't check in at a kiosk instead what
you want to do is go directly to the
check-in desk and speak with a live
representative the reason you want to do
that is because having a disability
you're going to have certain questions
concerns or accessibility requests that
you want to be sure to get straightened
out before you
even go through the process of trying to
get through security and make it to your
gate the other reason that you want to
check in with a live person is because
you need to get a destination tag for
your wheelchair and this is especially
important if you have a connecting
flight you obviously don't want to take
the chance of having your wheelchair be
rerouted to the wrong city which I have
heard of happening luckily it's never
happened to me but that's why you always
get a destination take for your
wheelchair my fourth don't for you is
don't assume that everybody who works at
the airport will automatically know how
best to assist you you need to be
assertive enough and have the confidence
to speak up voice your concerns and ask
the right questions to ensure that your
trip goes off as flawless as can be so
don't be afraid to speak up when you
need to all right so my fifth don't for
you is don't drink a ton of water before
your flight if you've ever been on an
airplane before and you know how small
the bathrooms can be they're not exactly
wheelchair friendly so what I find works
best for me is to not drink anything two
to three hours prior to my flight and
depending on the duration of the flight
I might not even drink anything on the
plane that's probably not feasible for
everyone to do and I understand that
this is just what works best for me so
experiment with some different things
see what works best for you if there are
things that I left out in this video or
other don'ts that you can think of best
practices that you follow be sure to
leave a comment below and let us know
what those are you can also follow me on
instagram at wheel dot traveled and with
that I will send it right back to you
mark thank you Joe and thank you Sarah
for the question I hope this can help
you out with your travels heading
forward and so we want to say have a
great weekend and we wish all the best
bye
